page.title: 14LANGUAGE/DIALECT IN CHAGFORD
page.content: As one moves around the area one is struck by the number and range of accents heard, particularly in the summer months when visitors are around. An appreciable number of locals still use the{Devon dialect}and it takes newcomers quite a while to learn to understand the vernacular. The following extract is taken from a story in the Chagford Bulletin{:-"Tho {d'r slamm'd, tho glass brok an I jis {thawt "that's thee lot, Will" wen a {voice vrom enzide zaid "that blim'in {wind, boy." "Twadn tho wind Mrs, {twas me- I vald up ginst tho d'r an' {out cum tho glass." }This shows the use of 'z' for 's' and 'v' for 'f', and the word 'vald' means 'fell'. While it would be a pity if the local dialect were to vanish, modern systems of communication increase the use of standardised English.
